data.title: BasicEffect and probably all Effect derivatives are leaking a lot of memory
data.body:
I have found that BasicEffect is leaking a lot of memory because: I have a gamepage that loads a game and unloads it in sync with the page and every time the game reloads the peak memory usage increases. This does not happen when I never create a basiceffect in the first place. I have tried to fix it myself but could not manage to achieve anything. I have though noticed that leaking starts as early as the initialization of the base class (Effect) so it might affect all other effects as well.

PS. I am calling dispose on the BasicEffect if any of you were wondering

Loading Shaders w/o Exec
Dynamically created textures are drawn upside down in PSMobile
Merge Desktop SoundEffect into main SoundEffect, AudioLoader to Desktop/
data.body:
This merges the SoundEffect found in `Desktop/Audio/SoundEffect.cs` into `Audio/SoundEffect.cs`. It also moves `AudioLoader.cs` to `Desktop/Audio/`, since the Windows and Linux versions were essentially the same file.

This should basically be the exact same code for all platforms, except now it's in single files and not several duplicates.

The only projects affected are Linux and WindowsGL.

data.title: Significantly improve OpenAL performance/memory usage.
data.body:
This pull request addresses two primary flaws in the current OpenAL audio backend for MonoGame:

**_1. Audio data is needlessly held on to after it has been given to OpenAL.**_

You will notice that we remove byte[] arrays in OALSoundBuffer and SoundEffectInstance in this patch. The code in those files implies that we need the data for purposes other than loading directly into OpenAL, but no code in MonoGame currently uses this. So, we essentially keep a duplicate copy of _every single OpenAL buffer_ for the duration of the program's runtime unless we explicitly destroy the data ourselves.

By simply removing these from the files, we improve memory use drastically, and for XACT, we improve it _by at least 50%_.

**_2. Redundant decoding/rewriting of wavedata is performed presumably to reuse the public API.**_

While it makes sense on paper, the fact is we're decoding header data only to reencode it when we're "done" in a single method multiple times for every single audio file that gets loaded into MonoGame. This can possibly introduce memory problems like those found in bullet one, and it's also a pretty goofy waste of resources when we can just send the data to internal methods that will eventually give it to OpenAL.

By fixing these two issues, performance for XACT/SoundEffects on OpenAL has improved immensely (mostly in regard to memory use, CPU use certainly improves but is not noticeable on high-end machines).

data.title: WP8 MediaPlayer 3100 error
data.body:
Hi! 

I have a problem with MediaPlayer. 
I use sources from developer branch (SDX binaries were taken from MonoGame dependencies on GitHub). 
When I call Play(Song) method, nothing happens.

I've modified source code of MediaPlayer and attached MediaFailed handler. 
It is always reports about 3100 error. 
Here are some extra details:
   3100 An error has occurred.

   ErrorTrace = Silverlight/4.1.60221.0
Tested on: Lumia 520, 920, Emulator with WMA and MP3. 
Resources were taken from WP7 application. 

 Could you please help me to fix that issue? Thanks.

data.title: Ability to write directly to the pixel back buffer
data.body:
(Or, failing that, directly manipulate texture or render target pixel data.)

I'm fairly inexperienced with game development in general, but I've done some stuff with XNA in the past, and now I'm trying to get back into it with MonoGame. I want to make a game that uses [Cairo](http://cairographics.org/) to draw some vectory goodness, but I'd like to use MonoGame as a framework because of how easy it makes the game loop and input functionality and stuff. Plus it can work cross-platform, sorta! So yeah, I'd like to not only make a game with Cairo and MonoGame, but also a framework to make other games like this. I'm a programmer and not an artist, so the idea of just drawing 2D stuff with math appeals to me.

[The problem I'm running up against](https://github.com/adamrezich/arena/blob/master/VGame/VGame.cs) is that it's just too darn slow to do what I'm doing, which is:
- Draw the scene with Cairo through a Cairo.Context to a Cairo.Surface every frame
- Copy the data from the Cairo.Surface to a Texture2D using SetData()
- Draw the Texture2D using SpriteBatch

Every single frame.

This is hecka slow, as it turns out! I've looked everywhere I can, but I can't seem to find any way of directly accessing the screen buffer and writing pixel data to it using MonoGame or XNA. Is there any chance at all that there could end up being a way of directly accessing the pixel buffer data to more easily facilitate this? I know it's kind of a niche issue, but hey, it never hurts to ask, right?

I see that XNA provides [GraphicsDevice.GetBackBufferData](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.graphics.graphicsdevice.getbackbufferdata.aspx)... is there any chance that this data could just be exposed and directly read from/written to?

I eventually also found [this](https://github.com/kevingadd/Fracture/blob/master/Squared/RenderLib/Evil.cs) (from [this article](http://www.altdevblogaday.com/2011/10/02/copying-pixels-from-a-pointer-to-an-xna-texture2d/), which a.) I'm assuming won't work in MonoGame because DirectX and b.) wouldn't be cross-platform because of the System.Reflection and such.

data.title: No option to clip the cursor to the window bounds in latest development version
data.body:
I'm making a game where, during gameplay, moving your cursor to the edges of the window (or screen if fullscreen) scrolls the camera. In MonoGame 3.0.1, this was easy; just set IsCursorVisible to false, and it would properly constrain your cursor to the window (at least, on Windows).

With the latest nightly DLLs in place, a bunch of other problems with 3.0.1 were fixed (resolution changing problems and such), but now the cursor is no longer bound to the window when hidden.

My friend running Linux claims that with the latest Linux DLLs, the cursor is bound to the window like it always was.

Is there some way this could be a toggleable bool or something, just like IsCursorVisible? I'd love for my game to constrain the cursor only during gameplay, but not while paused or in a menu while the game is in windowed mode.

data.title: Template for VS2012 installs in the incorrect location
data.body:
On irc, user reports:

[17:30] <Vandroiy> Oh what... the folder, is it really "Visual Studio 2012"? *tries that
[17:31] <Vandroiy> In case you still read this, it installs into the wrong folder. Correct name: "Visual Studio 11"
[17:31] <Vandroiy> I just moved the templates, and tadah there they are

the path should end with:

\Visual Studio 11\Templates\ProjectTemplates\Visual C#"

This was with version 3.0.1 of the published installer. Note that this installer worked for me on VS2012.

data.title: Fixes for Android Depth/Stencil buffer problems.
data.body:
It appears on some newer devices (Nexus 4) the defaults used by the AndroidGameView result in a surface without a depth or stencil buffer. This PR corrects the issue by attempting to use the PreferredDepthStencilFormat to pass in the correct parameters that the user wants. 

 Fixed an issue in AddSpecular where on certain android gpu's applying

the color.a to the specular wipes out the texture.

The fix is to apply it in two operations.

This has been tested on 4 different devices and emulator and works ok. 

If we had the xamarin test cloud we could know for sure but hey ho ;)

data.title: Linux windows can only resize when an MP3 is found in the content directory.
data.body:
A user on the monogame irc channel reports that this repo:

https://bitbucket.org/KinokoFuhen/pong-powerup

when built for Linux it only allows resizing when an mp3 is in the content output.

[20:11] <Kino> My window only resizes when there is a mp3 in 'Content' folder that the IDE is not aware of.
[20:11] <Kino> Kind of strange.
[20:12] <Kino> I notified the IDE, and magic, no more resize.
[20:13] <Kino> I added another mp3, and resize re-worked.

data.title: Dll reference problems, defaulting to WindowsPhone
data.body:
As I was fiddling with my projects to solve a problem, my WindowsGL project stopped building. I only had the default Game1 code and it was saying that GamePad class didn't existed it the current context. After some debugging I manage to find that it was using MonoGame WindowsPhone Assembly instead of WindowsGL by commenting the GamePad lines, I would get a null reference exception when trying to run the project. I re-re-re-re-re-rechecked the references, removed, re-added the correct one, and when I run it, always the same thing, null ref in the MonoGame WindowsPhone assembly.

Then I found out that as much as I had chose the WindowsGL assembly, after I hit the OK button it would reference the WindowsPhone one. I went to see the .csproj content and it hit me, the reference didn't had the path to the assembly, it was only referencing by the name and since there were at least 4 references with the same name, the first one was being picked or something like that. You can see the references in [this Gist](https://gist.github.com/vvolkgang/5924941). The first one is the reference I had and the second one is the default reference of the project template.

That being said, I believe that the problem appears if you add the reference in Visual Studio. I really don't know what can be done to fix this apart from issuing a documentation warning just in case.

I'm using Visual Studio 2012 and MonoGame 3.0.1 Stable.

data.title: Added an overload to SpriteBatch.Draw()
data.body:
While it's a small change, I've added a new overload to SpriteBatch.Draw() that wraps the two "large" Draw methods and makes all arguments following the Texture2D optional.  The intention is to simplify the process of invoking SpriteBatch.Draw() by allowing the user to call the method using named parameters instead of feeding in a long list of what are essentially default or null values in order to change a single property. 

This allows verbose draw calls such as:

``` csharp
spriteBatch.Draw(texture, playerRectangle, null, Color.White, 0f, Vector2.Zero, SpriteEffects.FlipHorizontally, 0f);
```

To be written more concisely and clearly:

``` csharp
spriteBatch.Draw(texture, drawRectangle: playerRectangle, effect: SpriteEffects.FlipHorizontally);
```

Another example, simply changing the rotation of a drawn sprite:

``` csharp
spriteBatch.Draw(texture, position: playerPosition, rotation: playRotation);
```

You can see where this is going.  I added this because I've always hated having to fill extraneous parameters in XNA just to add a rotation to a texture, for example.  Feedback appreciated.

data.title: Multi window touch input
data.body:
This PR contains the touch input changes discussed here: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/1731

The "state" information from TouchPanel has been moved into a TouchPanelState class. Each GameWindow owns a TouchPanelState object that contains input events for that window.

This only works on the DirectX Dekstop build, as it's currently the only that supports multiple windows.

The API for TouchPanel has remained the same.

To use new TouchPanelStateAPI, you'd do something like the following.

```
var touchState = TouchPanel.GetState(_mySecondaryGameWindow);

while (touchState.IsGestureAvailble)
    ProcessGameGesture(touchState.ReadGesture());
```

This allows for windows to independently handle touch input. I can only test on a couple of platforms, so let me know if this breaks functionality on another one.

data.title: GamePad.Update not being called on Android
data.body: Ran a test on Android, put in a break for Update(MotionEvent), it is never triggered. DId a reference search and the method is not used.

data.title: Make Vector2/3/4 more consistent, document them, and test them.
data.body:
This replaces the vast majority of the implementation bodies of Vector2/3/4 with a T4 template that generates their code. This increases consistency (a number of methods were only implemented in one or two dimensions for no reason), reduces errors, and reduces code duplication.

I also documented everything in Vector2/3/4.

I also added a test file to check all of the functionality.

I put in a Monogame.Framework.Documentation subdirectory for the SandCastle help file builder. I want to document everything.

There are two minor API changes. Vector2/3/4 have three purposes - as a tuple of float values, as a vector in the Physics sense, and as a position in space. Their APIs are a mishmash of all of these applications. But only \* and / scalar binary operators were implemented either here or in XNA, and from what I can tell it was because you can only scale physics vectors. I implemented binary scalar operators everywhere because that seemed pretty silly.

The other change is the addition of "%" as an operator.

data.title: RenderTarget2D issues on Qualcomm with LTE and Ardeno
data.body:
Dear developers,
we have recently published Doom & Destiny on Android thanks to Monogame, so i really need to thank you all for the huge work you have been doing in theese years.
We are having troubles with some customers, all of them have Qualcomm Galaxy S3 with LTE and GPU from Ardeno.
http://it.gsmchoice.com/it/catalogo/samsung/sghi535/

The issue is connected to a wrong RenderTarget binding that i cannot really test as i miss the required device. I found out this post on the BlackBerry/Gameplay project that might give some hint on the issue:
https://github.com/WolfgangD/GamePlay/blob/8438e3e8fde175107ef7f490e20a3ac83978826c/gameplay/src/FrameBuffer.cpp

I'm not doing anything strange in my code: creating a simple RT with no depthbuffer attached, but the results can be seen in theese pictures the customer are sending me: most of the framebuffers are completely vanished and the spritebatch depth sorting is completely nuts.

http://imageshack.us/a/img203/5707/4edv.png
http://imageshack.us/a/img401/7702/u1e.png

It would be great if someone with some skill with open gl or one of the Adreno 225 devices could check the rendertarget binding on the Android version.

Thanks a lot.
